[Letter] November 2nd, 1863 Winchester, Tennessee [to] Mr. Arthur Johnson
bibl.note: This letter from Union Sgt. Edward Summers, Co. K. Kentucky Calvary Regiment, is to his cousin Arthur Johnson on November 2, 1863. Summers gives a detailed account of his unit's movements following his enlistment on October 21, 1861 at Louisville, KY, including involvement in the Battle of Chickamauga.

div.p: Dear Cousen after my Very best Love to you, Mrs. Elizabeth Johnson and your Little Offspring, I again take my pen in hand for the fourth time Without an Answer to Let you know that I am Still On the Land amongst the Living. I Can again Say I, am Well and hope those fiew Lines may find you all Enjoying Same Blessing.. Peter, Mann,, Frank, Trueax,, F. W. Asbury,, Alexander, Curtis,, and all of Our Bracken Boys, are well and harty.. I have But Little News of Intrust at this time Every thing appears quiet Except Occasional Skermishes in the front and a fiew Gurriller Bands through Tennessee We have Bin Expecting. a heavy Battle for some two Weeks but it seams as if Bragg is incline to fall Back it may be his Object is to Draw Our troops away from Chatanooga. I,am Not With my Regiment at this time and I have a bad Chance of Gathering Information. I.am One of the Guards With the 1st Cav. Divisions, Ordnance train and it is hear at Winchester Tenn. Whaar it may in all probability Remain for Several Weeks My. Regiment and in fact My Whole Brigade is Encamped at Jeffers Ferry on the Tennessee River 2 Miles South of Stevenson Alabamia. I expect to Remain with this train all Winter it is an Easy position. and my fair are good My quarters are in a Neat Little Train House Near the Publick Squair I.Can See all that is going on in town in the Day time and have as many Yellow Girles in my Room at Night as I Wish but Enough of this

I.Will Now give you a Short Sketch of my travels Since I was at your house. When I.left home I went by the Way of Cynthaana and Georgetown to Lexington Ky I Was then Ordered to Report at Point Pleasant in Virginia. I.left Lexington on the 22nd of Last Oct. one year ago and passed through. Paris Millersburg the Blue Licks Washington, and On to Maysville Ky. I.their Crossed the Ohio River to Aberdeen and passed through Decature, Westunion Salem Jackson, Sciotiville Lucasville Galliopolis, and up the River to the mouth of the Big Kanawey River I their Crossed the Ohio River into Point Pleasant Virginia Whar I Joined my Command. We Drove the Enemy through Charlestown and Whiped them at Gawley Bridge and Drove them through Ashbys Gap in the Blue Ridge Mountains. We then Receivd Orders to Report at a point Near Vicksburg Misissippi. We Marched Back to Point Pleasant and their took Steam Boats to Cincinnati Ohio the Infantry went to Misissippi and Our Cavalry Was Ordered to Report at Lexington Ky We Bid a Due to the Queen City of the West and passed through Covington Williamstown Georgetown and On to Lexington Whar We Only Remained two Days to Rest from a Long and toilsome march of over 700 miles. We left Lexington Ky the Garden spot of the World with heavy hearts and marched,through Nicholassville Perryville Lebanon Danville Bloomfield, Springfield and On to Louisville Ky. We Only Remained their a Day or two to Rest Our Jaded horses We their took the Cars and passed through many town and Vilages and though the Green River Country to Nashville Tennessee the Capitol of

the State. We traversed the State all Over and,Over and Camped for a fiew Days at. Brentwood Franklen Springhill Shelbyville Tullahoma Triune Murfreesboro Winchester Fayattsville and many other towns after We had Skerged Tennessee Well We Then marched all of Our Cavalry forces into Alabamia Our first trip was to take Huntsville Ala. One of the finest towns I have Seen in Ala. We then took Stevenson and Bridgeport and many Other Little town the Enemy Still held Chatanooga. it is Situated on the Tennessee River about 2 1/2 miles from the Georgia State Line. Our Next moove was to take Chatanooga Which We Done Easily We then made a.Dashing Rade through Georgia tearing up the Rail Rode track Burning Bridges and Depoes and Cutting up hell in General. and O, God, O, God, the Scenes I have Witnessed. I have witnessed Some Dark and horrible Scenes Such as has made my Blood Run Cold. I, have, Seen men hung Like Dogs in Cool Blood. I, have Seen men Shot Down Like Broots in Cool Blood. I have Seen the flaming torch applide to fine Mills Large factories and Stately Mansions I.have Seen towns Raped in flames Besides innumerable Scenes of Disgust. I.have Seen the Rich made poor in a fiew Short hours. I have Seen Enough of the Horrors of War to Satisfy me and to Satisfy my mind that a Civil War Will Ruin any Nation under the Canopy of Heavan, it will Ruin all Classes of man kind the Whole World is Demoralized at this time and I.have underwent all the hardships Perils and privations that Belongs to a Soldiers Life I.have went through frost and Snow, through Rain and mud as well as the Scorching heat and bore it all.

as become a soldier I.have Bin in Nine Battles Besides a Number of Skermishes and by the help of God am yet Spard to tell the memorable tale of this Campaign I.have also Witnessed thousands and thousands of Most Butiful Sceneries Both Natural and Strange that was well Calculated to Interest the Weary Soldier as he passes by But the most Horrible Sight is the Battle field Yet, if you Could of Bin presant and of Looked Over the Battle field after the Battle of Chickamauga in Georgia and of Seen the Thousands apon top of thousands of Ded, Dying, and mangled masses of human Souls weltering in their Blood it would of Chilled Every Drop of Blood in your Veins wi the Whole face of the Earth appeard to be Covered with the Ded and Gorged with Blood Many of my Brave Companions fell in that memorable Battle By the Enemies fatal Ball and their Bones are left to Bleach apon the Georgia Plains I am Sorry to Inform you that Our Ded was Not Buried the Enemy took the field and held it Our Loss is Estimated at fifteen thousand and the Enemies at twenty Eight thousand, a Large Number of Souls to fall in One Battle and yet the War is Not at a Close Well Arthur I Shall have to Close for this time Give my Love to all of the friends and Relation and Answer Immediately Direct your Letter to Winchester Tennessee in the Care of Capt Wilson a.q.m. 1st Cav. Division and believe me to be Your Ever affectionate Cousen till Deth
pleas Send me a fiew Postage Stamps I can't get them hear
